sn22.151:4.2: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what,
sn22.151:4.3: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn22.151:4.4: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”
sn22.151:4.5: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form …
sn22.151:4.6: When consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness,
sn22.151:4.7: someone regards it like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’
sn22.151:4.8: What do you think, mendicants? Is form permanent or impermanent?”
sn22.151:4.10: “But without grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would you regard it like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn22.151:4.17: “But without grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would you regard it like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn22.151:4.20: They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’”
